channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Pulls Staff From Pakistan Consulate as Violence Continues
item.description: Americans are advised against traveling to Pakistan as mass killings continue to plague the nation.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Taiwan Drops Sanctions Against Philippines Over Fisherman’s Killing
item.description: Taipei accepted an apology from Manila for the fatal shooting in May of a Taiwan fisherman by the Philippine Coast Guard.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Bomb Attacks Kill Dozens of Mourners in Pakistan and Afghanistan
item.description: Bombers struck a funeral in western Pakistan and a graveyard across the border in Afghanistan, leaving at least 44 people dead on one of the holiest days on the Muslim calendar.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistan’s chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, second from left, at a funeral for police officers killed in a suicide attack.

item.title: Russia’s Stimulus Plan: Open the Gulag Gates
item.description: With tens of thousands of business owners in the gulag system, and with a depressed economy, President Vladimir Putin has an unusual plan to turn things around.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruslan V. Tyelkov spent a year in pretrial detention after being accused of copyright infringement for his wholesale upholstery business.

item.title: Leak at Oil Sands Project in Alberta Heightens Conservationists’ Concerns
item.description: Environmental concerns threaten the oil sands industry, which is pumping billions of dollars into the Canadian economy and providing thousands of jobs.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Attack on Officer’s Home Kills 13
item.description: After neighbors started to gather around the house, a nearby car bomb exploded, killing eight people and wounding 30.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Washington: Obama Urges Greece to Grow Economy
item.description: President Obama urged Greece on Thursday to find ways to build its economy even as it continues to cut spending in an effort to recover from a debt-driven economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Communist Party Expels Official
item.description: The party’s antigraft agency said Thursday that Liu Tienan, a powerful Chinese economic planning official, took bribes and abused his power.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Advertising: To Put Puerto Rico Onscreen, the Right Brands
item.description: The film “200 Cartas” (“200 Letters”) was financed in part through a careful collection of brand partnerships that will continue during its publicity campaign.
item.dc:creator: By TANZINA VEGA
item.media:description: “200 Cartas” (“200 Letters”) stars Lin-Manuel Miranda, left, with Jaime Camil.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Arrests Made in Girl’s Suicide
item.description: Police arrested two men on Thursday in the case of a teenager who died in April after a suicide attempt that followed months of cyberbullying.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: To American Watchdog on Afghan Reconstruction, Bluntness Is a Weapon
item.description: As the special inspector general for Afghan reconstruction, John F. Sopko says that “embarrassing people” is part of his job cataloging waste, mismanagement and fraud.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: John Sopko, the special inspector general for Afghan reconstruction, in his Arlington, Va., office.

item.title: Peace Talks to Resume in Jerusalem Next Week, State Dept. Says
item.description: After meeting in Jerusalem, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators will hold another session in Jericho on the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Commodity Imports Rise, Giving China Good News
item.description: Imports, as well as exports, were higher than expected in July, suggesting that policy makers in China may be starting to reverse an economic slowdown.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A Dongbei Special Steel Group factory in Dalian. Imports of iron ore rose 24 percent in July.

item.title: Amid Grief, Ex-Premier Resurfaces in Polish Race
item.description: Former Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski, known for his blunt comments, is a contender again in Polish politics because of a sagging economy and popular fatigue with the current leader.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski, known for railing against the European Union, seems to be toning down his language.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In an Airport Fire, Flames of Discord
item.description: Even a disaster couldn’t unite Kenyan society.
item.dc:creator: By MURITHI MUTIGA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Iran’s Plan B for the Bomb
item.description: Don’t let moderate talk from Tehran hide a rush to the nuclear finish line.
item.dc:creator: By AMOS YADLIN and AVNER GOLOV

item.title: Launching Site in Iran Raises Missile Worries
item.description: A previously undisclosed launching site and space center could theoretically be used for testing ballistic missiles, according to a report.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Rio De Janeiro Journal: Food-Safety Microscope on High-End Kitchens
item.description: Brazil is trying to improve restaurant standards as it prepares for the international attention that comes with the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspectors who this week raided Antiquarius — where prices have shocked many people in Rio — found more than 50 pounds of expired food.

item.title: Walking Funny and Fast Puts Russia City on Map
item.description: Four of the five top-ranked female distance race walkers in the world are from Saransk, an otherwise unremarkable city of about 310,000 people 320 miles southeast of Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Oksana Yushko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Champion race walkers Olga Kaniskina, second from right, and Elena Lashmanova, third from right, training in Saransk, Russia.

item.title: Bank of Japan Stands Pat on Monetary Easing Plan
item.description: Showing confidence on its efforts to counter deflation, Japan’s central bank voted to leave its monetary easing program unchanged.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: As Foreign Fighters Flood Syria, Fears of a New Extremist Haven
item.description: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Free Syrian Army fighters near the Menagh air base in Aleppo Province, which rebels captured this week after months of trying.

item.title: 12 in Yemen Die in Strikes by U.S. Drones
item.description: Since July 27, drone attacks have killed 34 suspected militants, according to a count provided by Yemeni security officials.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: International Flights Are Gradually Resumed at Airport in Nairobi
item.description: One day after a fire destroyed the airport’s main arrival hall, full operations were expected to be restored by the end of Thursday, but confusion still reigned at the check-in counters.
item.dc:creator: By REUBEN KYAMA and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Passengers waiting to board their flights at Nairobi’s Jomo Kenyatta International airport on Thursday.

item.title: Czech Parliament Seeks Way Out of Deadlock
item.description: The lower house of the Czech Parliament will vote next week on whether to dissolve itself and spur early elections in an effort to break a political deadlock.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Researchers Suspect That Camels Are Linked to a Middle East Virus
item.description: Scientists are reporting that dromedary camels from Oman and the Canary Islands show signs of past infection with the MERS virus or one very much like it.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: Camels may be a carrier of the virus that causes Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS).
